Appendix C Proof of Lemma 2

We will find where the IID distance for real-world DoL œàk(m)superscriptsubscriptùúìùëòùëö\psi_{k}^{(m)} converges as there are sufficient diffusion rounds. First of all, the IID distance for real-world DoL œàk(m)superscriptsubscriptùúìùëòùëö\psi_{k}^{(m)} is denoted as follows:

W1‚Äã(œàk(m),ùí∞)subscriptùëä1superscriptsubscriptùúìùëòùëöùí∞\displaystyle W_{1}(\psi_{k}^{(m)},\mathcal{U}) =‚à•œàk(m)‚àí1C‚Äãùüè‚à•absentdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùúìùëòùëö1ùê∂1\displaystyle=\left\lVert\psi_{k}^{(m)}-\frac{1}{C}\mathbf{1}\right\rVert (C.1)
=‚àëc=1C(œàk(m)‚Äã[c]‚àí1C)2absentsuperscriptsubscriptùëê1ùê∂superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùúìùëòùëödelimited-[]ùëê1ùê∂2\displaystyle=\sqrt{\sum_{c=1}^{C}\bigg{(}\psi_{k}^{(m)}[c]-\frac{1}{C}\bigg{)}^{2}}

There can exist two cases in the kùëòk-th diffusion round. One case is where the model mùëöm discovers the PUE possessing the optimal DSI. Another case is where the model mùëöm does not discover the PUE possessing the optimal DSI. In other words, the model discovers the PUE possessing real-world DSI. Suppose there exists a difference, namely, a variation œïk‚Äã[c]subscriptitalic-œïùëòdelimited-[]ùëê\phi_{k}[c] for two data sizes between the PUE possessing the real-world DSI and the optimal DSI as follows:

‚àëc=1Cœïk‚Äã[c]=Dik(m)‚àíDik(m)‚àó=D(ùí´k(m))‚àíD(ùí´k(m))‚àó,superscriptsubscriptùëê1ùê∂subscriptitalic-œïùëòdelimited-[]ùëêsubscriptùê∑superscriptsubscriptùëñùëòùëösuperscriptsubscriptùê∑superscriptsubscriptùëñùëòùëösubscriptùê∑superscriptsubscriptùí´ùëòùëösuperscriptsubscriptùê∑superscriptsubscriptùí´ùëòùëö\sum_{c=1}^{C}\phi_{k}[c]=D_{i_{k}^{(m)}}-D_{i_{k}^{(m)}}^{*}=D_{\left(\mathcal{P}_{k}^{(m)}\right)}-D_{\left(\mathcal{P}_{k}^{(m)}\right)}^{*}, (C.2)

where Dik(m)subscriptùê∑superscriptsubscriptùëñùëòùëöD_{i_{k}^{(m)}} and Dik(m)‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùê∑superscriptsubscriptùëñùëòùëöD_{i_{k}^{(m)}}^{*} denote the data size of the PUE possessing real-world DSI and the optimal DSI, respectively. Dik(m)subscriptùê∑superscriptsubscriptùëñùëòùëöD_{i_{k}^{(m)}} and Dik(m)‚àósuperscriptsubscriptùê∑superscriptsubscriptùëñùëòùëöD_{i_{k}^{(m)}}^{*} denote the total data size of the subchains, including the PUE possessing real-world and the optimal DSI, respectively. Please note that we focus on how the IID distance is derived according to the PUE participating at the kùëòk-th diffusion round, regardless of what data has been trained by the model until the (k‚àí1)ùëò1(k-1)-th diffusion round. Appendix D Additional experimental analysis

This section presents the additional experimental results mentioned in the main text. We additionally perform six experiments to demonstrate FedDif in the following scenarios:

  1. 1.

    Fig. 7 represents the performance of fully decentralized FedDif.

  2. 2.

    Fig. 8 represents the performance of FedDif with different probability distances.

  3. 3.

    Fig. 9 represents the performance of FedDif with Large-scale neural networks and complex dataset.

  4. 4.

    Fig. 10 represents the performance of re-trainable FedDif.

  5. 5.

    Fig. 11 represents the performance of FedDif with different weight initialization methods.

  6. 6.

    Fig. 12 represents the performance of FedDif based on the underlay mode of D2D communications.

All settings, such as the concentration parameter, minimum tolerable IID distance, and minimum tolerable QoS, of FedDif are the same as the main text described in Section VI-A.

D-A Scenario 1: fully decentralized FedDif

When the dedicated D2D channels exist for diffusion, FedDif can consider the fully decentralized FL. Fully decentralized FL is to remove the parameter aggregation server. Users delegate the representative to aggregate models or make a consensus to train models by in-network computing. We perform the experiments to delegate the representative and remove the role of BS. Figs. 7 describe the learning performance and communication costs in fully decentralized FedDif.

D-B Scenario 2: different probability distances

Based on the IID distance defined in Section III-B, FedDif measures how the DoL of the model is close to the IID data distribution. We basically employ Wasserstein-1 distance, but we can see that FedDif still works well, whatever other measurements can measure the similarity in Fig. 8. We perform experiments employing Kullback-Leibler divergence (KLD) and Jensen-Shannon divergence (JSD) to measure the IID distance.

D-C Scenario 3: large-scale neural networks and complex dataset

In the main text, we only demonstrate FedDif using simple ML models such as SVM, logistic regression, CNN, LSTM, and FCN. However, diffusing more complex models can require more communication resources. We first investigate the performance of FedDif using the ResNet34 model, which has 600 times larger than our basic CNN model described in Fig. 9. In the case of the complex dataset, more classes may increase the complexity of the ML task because the model should distinguish samples in finer-grained scope. A finer-grained scope may confuse the model when the probabilities of multiple classes are similar to each other. To demonstrate FedDif using the complex dataset, we perform experiments using the ResNet34 model and CIFAR100. Note that the CIFAR100 dataset has ten times more classes than the CIFAR10 dataset as the following Fig. 9.

D-D Scenario 4: re-trainable FedDif

In FedDif, PUEs cannot re-train the previously trained model by constraint (16c). In the local training step, allowing PUEs to retrain the model can induce biased training to a specific PUE‚Äôs non-IID data by continuously learning similar non-IID data. Consequently, it may rather put the brake on the improvement of learning performance, even yield the over-fitted global model. Another concern is that retraining may occur a ping-pong problem. When there are a few neighboring PUEs in the range satisfying the minimum tolerable QoS, PUEs may continuously give and take the model for a specific PUE. The ping-pong problem may deteriorate the performance of the global model by solely learning a particular distribution of non-IID data. To demonstrate it, we conduct the additional experiments removing the constraint (16c), and the following Fig. 10 describes the performance of re-trainable FedDif.

D-E Scenario 5: different weight initialization methods

Weight initialization can affect the upper bound of the weight difference. Specifically, as seen in proposition 1, the weight difference by the weight initialization is determined by the weight difference between the initial weight of the global model and local models. In the model broadcasting step, if each PUE updates the parameters of the local model to the global model received from the BS without error, the effect of weight initialization can be minimized. However, different weight initialization methods can affect the internal performance of FedDif. To demonstrate it, we perform additional experiments for different weight initialization methods, as shown in Fig. (11).

D-F Scenario 6: underlay mode of D2D communications

We perform additional experiments to consider the interference among different PUEs to investigate the communication efficiency of the underlay mode. In the additional experiments, we consider D2D communications underlying cellular networks in which each PUE only reuses the frequency resource of CUEs. Fig. 12 illustrates the performance of FedDif considering two different scenarios: the overlay and underlay mode of D2D communications. We can see that the learning performances of the two scenarios are similar, but the communication costs of the underlay mode are higher than the overlay mode. Although designing the optimal power control and resource allocation algorithms may improve the performance of FedDif utilizing the underlay mode of D2D communications, we focus on improving learning performance with non-IID data by increasing the diffusion rounds, and the resource allocation may be out of our scope.

D-G Additional investigation of the gap between the simulation and analytical results

As users have more heavily imbalanced data, the IID distance decreases steeply, starting from a higher point. This is because the more biased the model is, the faster it becomes affected by new data ever not seen before. Fig. 13 describes the convergence trends of IID distance by different concentration parameters. Note that the case of Œ±=100.0ùõº100.0\alpha=100.0 is the same as the distribution of the IID dataset. Each box plot and the shading areas around box plots represent the experimental and analytical boundary of IID distance, respectively. We confirm that Lemma 2 holds, and the models do not need to diffuse in the network where every user has the IID dataset.
